title: SHUTTLECRAFT - Run your own social media

last_post.content:
Hello fellow citizens of the free and open web, it is me, Ben Brown. You may remember me from that social network from back when social networks were cool, or maybe from that one open source project that blew up.

Hi, it is great to see you again.

First off, corporate owned social media always sucked, we always knew it. It is past time for us to have better options.I am so glad for the #Fediverse and #ActivityPub and Mastodon and other projects for breathing new life into the indie web, where it is possible for us to own what we post and use whatever tools we want. I couldn’t resist building something!

My new project is called SHUTTLECRAFT. It social media server … FOR ONE.

What does that mean?

It is very small and lightweight open source app that runs nicely on services like Glitch, but it has most of what you need to host your own personal social media account.

It’s got a microblogging tool, to make posts. You can customize the design with HTML and CSS. You can follow people on Mastodon or other services and interact with posts and send messages. People can follow you on Mastodon, or with RSS. You run it on your own server so you own and operate the data and the code and the whole service. And you can hack the code and make it weirder so that we can all be part of a better, more diverse and more interesting web.

No billionaires or mega-corps required!

I made a 3 minute video showing how it works:
https://www.loom.com/share/a6441bcebdc64f54b5010c95eae1e180

Though this a personal project and only a few weeks old, with tons of stuff still unfinished and yet to build... you can get the code right now and run your own right now! The official site also has a 3 minute walk through of setting up an instance on Glitch. It is pretty easy!

https://shuttlecraft.net/

Or go straight to for the code:

https://github.com/benbrown/shuttlecraft

Thanks to everyone who has already tested this or sent feedback or contributed code. Y'all rule.

Own your posts!! Make it hard for them to monetize you!

last_post.content:
Muzzled by DeSantis, Critical Race Theory Professors Cancel Courses or Modify Their Teaching
--
It’s easy to dismiss the conservative crusade against #CRT as political theater without real consequences. But most colleges & universities offer social science and humanities courses that address racial inequality and systemic racism, and the anti-CRT laws are already having repercussions for people who teach or take these classes in red states.

#race #education #Florida

title: Opinion | Once an Open Sewer, New York Harbor Now Teems With Life. Thank the Clean Water Act.

last_post.content:
50 years ago, the harbor of New York City was a sewer, filled with human trash and pollutants

But congress passed the Clean Water Act and it helped enormously, so …

… today wildlife has staged a remarkable comeback, and the water quality is high. They’ve seen humpback whales in the Hudson River one mile from Times Square, and there’s a thousand breeding pairs of heron

Smart ecological legislation works

When electronics importer Cara Leon goes missing, private investigator Sam Mujrif is hired by her sister to investigate. Cara is 8 times taller than Sam, but evidence soon points to players much smaller than either of them.

As Sam and his cross-scale colleagues pursue the case, it becomes apparent that Cara’s disappearance is linked to technology with the potential to reshape their whole society, and radically alter the balance of power between the scales.

https://www.gregegan.net/SCALE/SCALE.html

"What should I measure when the CEO asks for engineering metrics?" is probably the most frequently recurring eng leadership question, and connects into a larger, somewhat nebulous topic: how should you measure engineering organizations?

The biggest challenge with answering this question directly imo is that there are a number of different stakeholders who all want very different things. Literal answers anchor on one stakeholders rather than solving for whole set.

https://lethain.com/measuring-engineering-organizations/

title: A Crucial Particle Physics Computer Program Risks Obsolescence

last_post.content:
“I have seen over the years, consistently, that people who spend a lot of time on computers don’t get a tenure job in physics,” said Vermaseren.

“It’s more prestigious, maybe, to actually produce physical results than to work on tools,” said Ruijl.

And this is how we keep pushing people towards career death, burnout due to overwork or out of academia entirely.

https://www.wired.com/story/a-crucial-particle-physics-computer-program-risks-obsolescence/

title: Sidekiq quere flooded with LowPriorityWorker for "Delete Actor" pull · Discussion #18347 · mastodon/mastodon

last_post.content:
Spotted an interesting Mastodon attack, currently low key - people creating, then deleting accounts. This causes the instance to send messages to every Fediverse instance to delete the content, causes the pull queue to bloat in Sidekiq. #fediadmin

See also: https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/discussions/18347

Looking for something fun to do in 2023? Why not learn how to hack mainframes :blobcatthinkingsunglass:​ ?

This container was built for our DEFCON 30 workshop. It will walk you through three challenging buffer overflows on a real mainframe OS. The first challenge is a simple C program buffer overflow, the second a buffer overflow and privesc and finally remote code execution over FTP.

https://hub.docker.com/r/mainframed767/defcon30

#defcon #mainframe #bufferoverflow #hacking #free

title: The tragedy of the commons is a false and dangerous myth | Aeon Essays

last_post.content:
The tragedy of the commons is a pernicious myth.

The demise of the commons of Britain and Europe wasn't the result of misuse by commoners, but enclosing by the landowners. The original hypothetical was made up for storytelling purposes, and the term was popularized by an ecologist with anti-immigrant and racist views.

Here is my recommended reading for heading into 2023:

https://aeon.co/essays/the-tragedy-of-the-commons-is-a-false-and-dangerous-myth

Shepard interpolation is a surprisingly simple multi-dimensional interpolation method. It uses singular radial basis functions inversely proportional to the distances to the samples. Nearest neighbor interpolation is the limit case. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse_distance_weighting

title: Generating a nice-looking PDF with Pandoc

last_post.content:
I wanted to write a blog post about generating a smart, modern-looking PDF from markdown using #Pandoc. I also use markdown for my blog (can you tell where this is going?) and I needed an image to illustrate adding borders to screenshots.

Please enjoy this blog post with accompanying PDF version of the exact same content, and including a screenshot of the blog version of the content because this wasn't meta enough already https://lornajane.net/posts/2023/generating-a-nice-looking-pdf-with-pandoc #projects

title: Shopify Tells Employees to Just Say No to Meetings

last_post.content:
A few days ago, I encouraged canceling all recurring meetings in the new year and only adding them back if truly necessary.

Shopify just did that at a company level by banning recurring meetings with over 2 people and now large meetings only on Thursdays.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-01-03/shopify-ceo-tobi-lutke-tells-employees-to-just-say-no-to-meetings

JOB ANNOUNCEMENT!

Reposting since I moved instances -- please spread widely.

We're hiring at the Assistant/Associate #Professor level in the Complex Human Data Hub at #UniMelb.

It's a combined #research and #teaching position, for researchers who study any topic within #mathematical or #computational #cognitive/#social science (broadly construed). We're especially interested in applications from #women and #minorities.

Closing date is Feb 2nd, and all details can be found at the link below. Melbourne is awesome and so are we so come join us!

https://psychologicalsciences.unimelb.edu.au/chdh/news/we-are-hiring

@tiago

A new kid on the block released less than two months ago. CausalPy is based on @pymc_labs PyMC - a well-established probabilistic programming framework in Python. CausalPy has been developed by PyMC’s prolific @benvincent with contributions from Wolt’s excellent data scientist @juanitorduz. CausalPy implements a bunch of methods to work with quasi-experimental data. Everything in Bayesian fashion!

filter: https://observablehq.com/@neocartocnrs/filter-geojson?collection=@neocartocnrs/geotoolbox

For junior researchers on the #Economics of #Migration —> a very nice conference in Paris this June.

Intended for PhD students, post-docs, and assistant professors less than three years out.

Joint initiative of CERDI, PSE, LISER, the University of Luxembourg, Universidad Carlos III, CEPII, and the IC Migrations. Keynotes by the brilliant Cátia Batista, Simone Bertoli, and Frédéric Docquier

Submissions due Feb. 15 at—> https://economig.sciencesconf.org #LaborEcon #Conference #Immigration #CallForPapers

Okay, #Hometown v1.1.0 is now released!

Massive release notes here:

https://github.com/hometown-fork/hometown/releases/tag/v4.0.2%2Bhometown-1.1.0

Admins, please let me know if you run into trouble on the upgrade. This is a tricky one, mostly due to Mastodon v3 -> v4 stuff. You'll get a lot of mileage searching the Mastodon issues repo for production errors you run into on the upgrade.

I'll repeat what I said on the release notes: if your installation is customized in any way (sidekiq setup, etc) you NEED to be careful.

title: Finland ends homelessness and provides shelter for all in need - scoop.me

last_post.content:
“In #Finland, the number of homeless people has fallen sharply. Those affected receive a small apartment and counselling with no preconditions. 4 out of 5 people affected make their way back into a stable life. And all this is CHEAPER than accepting homelessness.”

Make sure everyone understands this — It’s costing us far too much to NOT provide housing and supports to those who are homeless.

https://scoop.me/housing-first-finland-homelessness/

#homelessness #cities #housing #HousingFirst

title: Long Out of Math, an AI Programmer Cracks a Pure Math Problem | Quanta Magazine

last_post.content:
Some progress on the #FranklConjecture!

Justin Gilmer used some information theoretic arguments to establish the first constant lower bound for the fraction of sets in a #UnionClosed family that contain the same element. Initially 1%, now 38% but it looks like some new ideas are required to get to the 50% of the conjecture.

Quanta article: https://www.quantamagazine.org/long-out-of-math-an-ai-programmer-cracks-a-pure-math-problem-20230103/

Gilmer’s paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.09055

The U.S. Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP) published a roadmap today for research on information integrity:
https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/Roadmap-Information-Integrity-RD-2022.pdf

They outline four priority areas: 1) modeling & analyzing info ecosystems; 2) investigating safeguards (e.g. media literacy) to support healthier engagement with information; 3) envisioning technical approaches to support information integrity; 4) developing/evaluating strategies for addressing manipulative information campaigns.
The 4th Workshop on Human-AI Co-creation with Generative Models is happening at IUI 2023 in March. Submit your work by Jan 9! https://hai-gen.github.io/2023/ #genai #hci #creativity
Are you scared of ptrace()? Come write a high-performance debugger for Linux which is designed for low-overhead debugging of many-threaded and multi-process applications https://www.twitch.tv/gamozo

The American Physical Society have updated results from their ethics in physics survey. It allows a comparison to their 2002 survey. Unsurprisingly, more work is still needed. Not just around research practices but also professional conduct.

Frances Houle, Kate Kirby and Michael Marder put this into a nice context in their comment piece.

https://physicstoday.scitation.org/doi/full/10.1063/PT.3.5156
